metadata.case_name: Cooperative Society (Petitioner) v. Regional Transport Authority Aurangabad & Ors.

facts.text: The petitioner is a cooperative society duly registered and carries on the business of plying motor buses as stage carriages on the public highways in the State of Bombay.
Petitioner had permits to run buses on four routes in Aurangabad, due to expire on October 1, 1958.
State of Bombay (third respondent) had permits for two of these four routes.
On May 19, 1958, State of Bombay applied for permits for all four routes under Chapter IV of the Motor Vehicles Act.
On May 27, 1958, petitioner applied for renewal of its existing permits.
Regional Transport Authority (respondent No. 1) rejected petitioner's application and granted those of State of Bombay.
Petitioner's appeal to State Transport Authority (respondent No. 2) was rejected.
Petitioner granted temporary permits up to December 31, 1958.
Bombay High Court under Art. 226 quashed orders of respondents 1 and 2 and directed reconsideration of applications.
Respondent No. 1 granted temporary permits to State of Bombay without reconsidering; High Court quashed this order.
On March 20, 1959, respondent No. 1 granted temporary permits to petitioner, extended to July 20, 1959.
On June 1, 1959, State of Bombay published a scheme under s. 68C of Chapter IVA; objections filed, no further action.
On July 18, 1959, respondent No. 1 reconsidered applications, rejected petitioner's and allowed State of Bombay's.
Petitioner's temporary permits expired on July 20, 1959; ceased operating buses.
Petition filed in Supreme Court on August 27, 1959 under Art. 32 seeking writs quashing order dated July 18, 1959, restraining State from applying under Chapter IV, etc.

legal_issues.text: Whether the State of Bombay was entitled to apply for permits under Chapter IV of the Motor Vehicles Act despite the existence of Chapter IVA.
Whether the grant of permits to State over petitioner as cooperative society infringes Art. 14, denying preference under proviso to s. 47(1).
Whether Chapter IV permitting State to compete with private citizens offends Art. 14 due to State's vast resources.
Whether the order of respondent No. 1 dated July 18, 1959 infringes petitioner's fundamental rights under Arts. 19(1)(g) and 14.

petitioner_arguments.text: In view of Chapter IVA, State had no right to apply for permits under Chapter IV; order granting permits to State illegal, infringing Art. 19(1)(g).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Motor Vehicles Act Ch IVA; Nazir Ahmad v. King Emperor; expressum facit cessare tacitum

petitioner_arguments.text: State transport undertaking cannot apply under Ch IV as not 'owner' under s. 42; s. 47 does not contemplate Govt applications.
As cooperative society, entitled to preference over Govt (individual owner) under proviso s. 47(1); RTA considered future promises, not existing conditions.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Proviso to s. 47(1) MV Act; Art. 14

petitioner_arguments.text: Ch IV allows unfair competition by State due to resources, offending Art. 14.

respondent_arguments.text: State entitled to apply under Ch IV as owner for commercial purposes post-1956 amendment; Ch IVA provides alternative advantage, not exclusive.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s. 42(3)(a) MV Act; Ch IV and IVA independent

court_reasoning.text: Nazir Ahmad principle applies only where one power given; here Ch IV and IVA provide independent powers; post-1956, Govt must get permits under s. 42(1) like others for commercial buses.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Govt can apply under Ch IV; Ch IVA gives special right under approved scheme.

court_reasoning.text: s. 42(3)(a) plain: Govt as owner needs permit for commercial transport; s. 68F contemplates State undertaking applying under Ch IV.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Govt is owner; maxim expressum facit cessare tacitum inapplicable to plain language.

court_reasoning.text: No discrimination in s. 42 post-amendment; Moti Lal observations on old clause irrelevant.
Proviso s. 47(1) gives coop preference over individuals; if Govt not individual, no preference but still eligible applicant; RTA quasi-judicial, errors remediable separately.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No Art. 14 violation in RTA decision.

court_reasoning.text: Art. 19(6) contemplates State competing in business; no grievance under Art. 14 from competition.
court_reasoning.key_observation: State may compete partially or fully.

holdings.text: State of Bombay entitled to apply for and obtain permits under Chapter IV of MV Act.
No infringement of Art. 19(1)(g) or Art. 14 by State's application under Ch IV or grant of permits.
RTA's decision does not offend Art. 14; quasi-judicial errors not fundamental rights violation.

precedents_cited.relevance: Principle of doing thing in specified way only applies where single power; not here with two chapters.
Statutory power conferred first time with mode means no other mode; distinguished as multiple powers here.
Construe statute from natural meaning, considering prior law/mischief; Ch IVA not exclusive.

precedents_cited.case_name: Moti Lal v. Government of Uttar Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Old s. 42(3)(a) discriminatory; amended version not.

statutes_cited.name: Motor Vehicles Act, 1939 (as amended by Act 100 of 1956)
statutes_cited.relevance: Regulates permits for transport vehicles; Ch IV general, Ch IVA special for State undertakings giving permit as matter of right post-scheme.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Alleged infringement by discrimination and business restriction; Art. 19(6) allows State competition.

outcome.summary: Court rejected petitioner's contentions that State could not apply under Chapter IV and that grants infringed Arts. 14 and 19(1)(g); held State entitled to apply under Ch IV independently of Ch IVA; no fundamental rights violation.

key_quotes.text: "where a power is given to do a certain thing in a certain way the thing must be done in that way or not at all."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Cites and distinguishes Nazir Ahmad principle.

key_quotes.text: The Act lays down two independent sets of provisions in regard to the running of buses by the Government, one, under Chapter IV and the other under Chapter IVA.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Art. 19(6) ... would seem to indicate that the State may carry on any business either as a monopoly, complete or partial, or in competition with any citizen.
key_quotes.speaker: court
